Area of plane figures

1. Area of quadrilaterals


ID is: 2004 Seed is: 9244

Perimeter and area involving pythagoras

Study the figure OPQRS below. The figure is drawn to scale.

Side OP=10cmOP=10cm , PQ=PQ= Not given, QR=5cmQR=5cm, RS=xRS=x, SO=7cmSO=7cm.

Calculate the perimeter and the area of the figure. Round your answer to one decimal place.

Answer:
  1. Perimeter = cmcm
  2. Area = cm2cm2
numeric
numeric

STEP: <no title>
[4 points 0 / 4 points left]

You first need to calculate the value of xx.

xx = 11.211.2 cmcm

The perimeter = 40.240.2 cmcm

The area =9595cm2cm2

  • We need to notice 3 things from the given information:

    1. PQ=OSPQ=OS (Opposite sides of a rectangle are equal)
    2. OP=QSOP=QS (Opposite sides of a rectangle are equal
    3. x is the hypotenuse side of right QRS. Using the Theorem of Pythagoras:
      RS2=QR2+SQ2RS2=(5)2+(10)2RS=125RS=11.2cmRS2=QR2+SQ2RS2=(5)2+(10)2RS=125RS=11.2cm

  • Perimeter is the border or outer boundary of a two-dimensional figure.

    Perimeter=Sum of the distance around=10+7+5+11.2+7=10+7+5+11.2+7Perimeter=40.2cmPerimeter=Sum of the distance around=10+7+5+11.2+7=10+7+5+11.2+7Perimeter=40.2cm
  • Area is the amount of space inside the boundary of a two-dimensional shape.
AreaA=lengthwidth=107=70cm2AreaB=12baseheight=12(105)=25cm2AreaTotal=AreaA+AreaB=95cm2AreaA=lengthwidth=107=70cm2AreaB=12baseheight=12(105)=25cm2AreaTotal=AreaA+AreaB=95cm2

Area formulae for the basic shapes

For each of the shapes shown below, identify the correct formula for the area of the shape.

Shape A Shape B
Choice Area Formula
1 A=b2A=b2
2 A=bhA=bh
3 A=h2(a+b)A=h2(a+b)
4 A=r2A=r2
5 None of the above
Answer:

Shape A:

Shape B:

2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[0 points 2 / 2 points left]
Look in your textbook or follow this link to get to a summary of the Area Formulae.
STEP: <no title>
[2 points 0 / 2 points left]

Area is the surface of a shape or object that you can cover or paint. The pictures below show the shapes in the question "painted" in a colour; the painted place is the area of the shape.

You need to memorise each of the area formulae!!

  • Parallelogram: A parallelogram looks like the picture below. The correct formula for the area of a parallelogram is Aparallelogram=bhAparallelogram=bh. It is very important that the base (b) and the height (h) are perpendicular to each other. (You may notice that this is the same as the formula for the area of a rectangle.)

  • Trapezium: A trapezium looks like the picture below. The correct formula for the area of a trapezium is Atrapezium=h2(a+b)Atrapezium=h2(a+b). The two parallel sides of the trapezium (a and b) must be perpendicular to the height (h) of the trapezium.

Area is the surface of a shape or object that you can cover or paint. The pictures below show the shapes in the question "painted" in a colour; the painted place is the area of the shape.

You need to memorise each of the area formulae!!

  • Square: A square looks like the picture below. The correct formula for the area of a square is Asquare=b2Asquare=b2. The area is just the product of the two (equal) sides.

  • Circle: A circle looks like the picture below. The correct formula for the area of a circle is Acircle=r2Acircle=r2. The number 'r' is the radius of the circle.

ID is: 2007 Seed is: 9532

Perimeter and area

Study the figure below and calculate the perimeter and the area of this figure by using the given lengths in mm.

Answer:
  1. Perimeter = mm
  2. Area = m2m2
numeric
numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[0 points 2 / 2 points left]

For the perimeter, you need to find the sum (the total) of the distance around the edges of the shape. For the area, you will need to use what you know about the area of rectangles.

STEP: Find the perimeter
[1 point 1 / 2 points left]

The perimeter of an object is the distance around the outer boundary of a two-dimensional figure. For example, the perimeter of a soccer field is the white line around the entire field. The diagram below shows the perimeter coloured red and blue.

To find the perimeter, we need to add up all six sides of the shape. We can start at any corner we want and go around until we get back where we started. We will start at the corner labelled below.

Perimeter=Sum of the distance around=6+6+3+2+3+4Perimeter=24mPerimeter=Sum of the distance around=6+6+3+2+3+4Perimeter=24m
NOTE: You do not have to start at the same corner: you can start at any corner and you will get the same total distance. This is because the distance around the shape is the same no matter where you start.
STEP: Break the shape into rectangles to find the area
[1 point 0 / 2 points left]

The area of a shape is the amount of surface inside the boundary of the shape. If you paint a shape, you are painting the area of the shape.

To calculate the area in this case, we need to break the shape into familar shapes like triangles or rectangles. In the case above you have two rectangles. The rectangles are labelled AA and BB. Find the area of each rectangle and then add them together to get the total area of the shape.

AreaA=lengthwidth=64=24cm2AreaB=lengthwidth=32=6cm2AreaTotal=AreaA+AreaB=30m2AreaA=lengthwidth=64=24cm2AreaB=lengthwidth=32=6cm2AreaTotal=AreaA+AreaB=30m2

Therefore, the perimeter is 24 m24 m, and the area is 30 m230 m2.

Submit your answer as: and

ID is: 2005 Seed is: 9970

Missing lengths

Study the figure XYWVUXYWVU below. The figure is drawn to scale.

Side XY=15kmXY=15km , YW=YW= Not given , WV=20kmWV=20km , VU=25kmVU=25km , UX=10.8kmUX=10.8km.

Calculate the perimeter and the area of the figure. Round your answer to two decimal places.

Answer:
  1. Perimeter = kmkm
  2. Area = km2km2
numeric
numeric
2 attempts remaining
STEP: <no title>
[5 points 0 / 5 points left]

YW=XUYW=XU (Opposite sides of a rectangle are equal)

The perimeter = 81.681.6 kmkm

The area = 312312km2km2

Perimeter is the border or outer boundary of a two-dimensional figure - the "distance " you would walk around the shape. In this specific case above, you follow the red lines XYXY and YWYW, then the blue lines WVWVand VUVU, then the final red line UXUX back to the start. Remember you are only adding distances in one dimension so the unit for your answer will be kmkm only.

Perimeter=Sum of the distance around=15+10.8+20+25+10.8=15+10.8+20+25+10.8Perimeter=81.6kmPerimeter=Sum of the distance around=15+10.8+20+25+10.8=15+10.8+20+25+10.8Perimeter=81.6km

Area is the amount of space inside the boundary of a two-dimensional shape - the " space " inside the perimeter. To calculate the area try and divide the compound shape into simpler shapes with a familiar formula. In the case above you have areaAA a rectangle and areaBB a triangle. Remember you are multiplying kmkm by kmkm which means your unit for your answer shoud be kmkm22.

AreaA=lengthwidth=1510.8=162km2AreaB=12baseheight=12(1520)=150km2AreaTotal=AreaA+AreaB=312km2AreaA=lengthwidth=1510.8=162km2AreaB=12baseheight=12(1520)=150km2AreaTotal=AreaA+AreaB=312km2

Therefore, the perimeter = 81.6km and the area = 312km22.

2. Area of triangles


ID is: 4407 Seed is: 4651

Height of a triangle

Answer the following questions about triangles.

  1. Choose the correct formula for the area of a triangle.

    In the options below, bb stands for base and hh stands for height.
    Answer:
    HINT: <no title>
    [0 points 2 / 2 points left]

    The area of a triangle is always half the area of a parallelogram with the same base and height.

    STEP: Choose the correct formula
    [2 points 0 / 2 points left]
    Area is the amount of flat space taken up by a shape.

    To understand where the formula comes from, let us think about this triangle:

    We can draw a rectangle around the triangle so that:

    • the length of the rectangle is equal to the base of the triangle, and
    • the breadth of the rectangle is equal to the height of the triangle.

    Notice that our triangle is made of two right-angled triangles, XX and YY. But, the space taken up by Triangle XX is the same as Triangle XX. Also, the space taken up by Triangle YY is the same as Triangle YY.

    So, the shaded area of our triangle (XX and YY) is equal to the unshaded area in the rectangle (XX and YY). This means that the space taken up by our triangle is equal to half of the space taken up by a rectangle with the same base and height.

    The area of the rectangle is: A=baseheightA=baseheight.

    The area of the triangle is half of this, so the formula for the area of a triangle is:

    A=12bhA=12bh
    NOTE:

    The formula can be written in slightly different ways. They all mean the same thing:

    • A=12bhA=12bh
    • A=12bhA=12bh
    • A=bh2A=bh2
    • A=12(bh)A=12(bh)
    Submit your answer as:

  2. Consider the diagram of PRQPRQ:

    If PRPR is the base of triangle PRQPRQ, what is the height that goes with the base?

    Answer:
    HINT: <no title>
    [0 points 2 / 2 points left]

    The height of a triangle depends on the base. The height must

    • be perpendicular to the base, and
    • cover the distance between the base and the third vertex.
    STEP: Identify the height
    [2 points 0 / 2 points left]

    The height of a triangle must be perpendicular to one of the sides of the triangle, and it must cover the distance between that side and the third vertex. This side is called the base, even if it isn't at the bottom of the triangle.

    NOTE: Perpendicular means that the lines meet at 9090. This is shown with a little square at the angle. We write an upside down letter T, "base height", to mean that the base is perpendicular to the height.

    The base in this question is PRPR. QSQS is perpendicular to the base and covers the distance between the base and the third vertex (QQ). So, QSQS is the height.

    This is easier to see when the base is horizontal:

    Submit your answer as:

    • the breadth of the rectangle is equal to the height of the triangle.

    Notice that our triangle is made of two right-angled triangles, XX and YY. But, the space taken up by Triangle XX is the same as Triangle XX. Also, the space taken up by Triangle YY is the same as Triangle YY.

    So, the shaded area of our triangle (XX and YY) is equal to the unshaded area in the rectangle (XX and YY). This means that the space taken up by our triangle is equal to half of the space taken up by a rectangle with the same base and height.

    The area of the rectangle is: A=baseheightA=baseheight.

    The area of the triangle is half of this, so the formula for the area of a triangle is:

    A=12bhA=12bh
    NOTE:

    The formula can be written in slightly different ways. They all mean the same thing:

    • A=12bhA=12bh
    • A=bh2A=bh2
    • A=12bhA=12bh
    • A=12(bh)A=12(bh)
    Submit your answer as:

  2. Consider the diagram of RQPRQP:

    If RPRP is the base of triangle RQPRQP, what is the height that goes with the base?

    Answer:
    HINT: <no title>
    [0 points 2 / 2 points left]

    The height of a triangle depends on the base. The height must

    • be perpendicular to the base, and
    • cover the distance between the base and the third vertex.
    STEP: Identify the height
    [2 points 0 / 2 points left]

    The height of a triangle must be perpendicular to one of the sides of the triangle, and it must cover the distance between that side and the third vertex. This side is called the base, even if it isn't at the bottom of the triangle.

    NOTE: Perpendicular means that the lines meet at 9090. This is shown with a little square at the angle. We write an upside down letter T, "base height", to mean that the base is perpendicular to the height.

    The base in this question is RPRP. QTQT is perpendicular to the base and covers the distance between the base and the third vertex (PP). So, QTQT is the height.

    NOTE: The height does not need to be drawn on the inside of the triangle.

    • 1 cm1 cm == 10 mm10 mm
    • 1 m1 m == 100 cm100 cm
    • 1 km1 km == 1,000 m1,000 m
    STEP: Check that the units are consistent
    [2 points 0 / 2 points left]

    When calculating area, all of the measurements need to be consistent.

    TIP: Consistent measurements mean that all of the units are the same. For example, all of the measurements can be in mm, or all in cmcm. They cannot be a mixture of mm and cmcm.

    In this question, the base was given as 18 m18 m, and the height as 500 cm500 cm. So, we must convert the units (into either mm or cmcm) before doing any calculations.

    • 1 cm1 cm == 10 mm10 mm
    • 1 m1 m == 100 cm100 cm
    • 1 km1 km == 1,000 m1,000 m

    Tlotliso correctly converted 500 cm500 cm to 5 m5 m before doing any calculations. She used consistent units and did the calculations correctly.

    Hafsah correctly converted 18 m18 m to 1,800 cm1,800 cm before doing any calculations. She used consistent units and did the calculations correctly.

    So, both Tlotliso and Hafsah are correct.

  2. Compare the areas calculated by Tlotliso and Hafsah.

    HINT: <no title>
    [0 points 2 / 2 points left]

    Tlotliso and Hafsah have both correctly calculated the area of the same triangle. They have just used different units in their calculations.

    STEP: Compare the areas
    [2 points 0 / 2 points left]

    Tlotliso and Hafsah have both correctly calculated the area of the same triangle. They have just used different units in their calculations. So, 45 m2=450,000 cm245 m2=450,000 cm2.

    This means that 1 m2=10,000 cm21 m2=10,000 cm2. This might surprise you, because 1 m=100 cm1 m=100 cm. You might have expected units of area to convert in the same way. But, that is not the case!

    We can understand this by looking at a centimetre square, which shows 1 cm21 cm2 (not drawn to scale).

    We know that each cmcm contains 10 mm10 mm:

    We can now divide the square up into millimetre squares (mm2mm2):

    There are 1010 rows, each containing 1010 small squares, so there are 1010=1001010=100 millimetre squares in one centimetre square! This means that 1 cm2=100 mm21 cm2=100 mm2.

    We can also see this algebraically:

    1 cm2=(1 cm)(1 cm)=(10 mm)(10 mm)=100 mm21 cm2=(1 cm)(1 cm)=(10 mm)(10 mm)=100 mm2

    In the same way:

    1 m2=(1 m)(1 m)=(100 cm)(100 cm)=10,000 cm21 m2=(1 m)(1 m)=(100 cm)(100 cm)=10,000 cm2

    Area is measured in square units. So, to convert units of area, we multiply or divide by the squared number that we would use for linear conversions. For example, to convert from cmcm to mmmm we multiply by 1010. To convert from cm2cm2 to mm2mm2, we multiply by 102=100102=100.

Conservation of area: triangles

Consider the shaded area of Shape X below.

Which of the following shapes has the same amount of shaded area as Shape X?

NOTE: All of the shapes in this question are drawn to scale. The outside rectangles are all the same size.
Answer:
HINT: <no title>
[0 points 2 / 2 points left]

If triangles have the same base and height, they will have the same area.

STEP: Compare the base and height of each triangle to Shape X
[2 points 0 / 2 points left]
If triangles have the same base and height, they will have the same area.

Shape X has a base equal to the length of the rectangle, and a height equal to the breadth:

Option A has the same height as Shape X, but a shorter base. So, its area is less than Shape X.

Option B has the same base and height as Shape X. So, its area is the same as Shape X.

Option C is made up of a triangle with the same area as Shape X, plus an extra shaded part. So, its area is greater than Shape X.

So, only Option B has the same area as Shape X.

3. Area of circles & sectors


ID is: 4387 Seed is: 5063

Choose the formula

Choose the correct formula for calculating the circumference of a circle:

Answer:
HINT: <no title>
[0 points 2 / 2 points left]

Area is measured in unit squares, and there is a square in the area formula. Circumference is measured in units of length, so nothing is squared in the circumference formula.

STEP: Choose the correct formula for circumference of a circle
[2 points 0 / 2 points left]
The circumference of a circle is the same as the perimeter of a circle. It is the distance around the edge of the circle.

The circumference of a circle is a curve and it is not easy to measure. But, mathematicians have worked out that there is a special relationship between the diameter of a circle and its circumference.

For any circle, not matter how big or small, if you divide the circumference (CC) by the diameter (dd) you will get a number close to 33. The more accurately you measure the circumference and diameter, the closer you will get to this special number:

Cd=3.14159Cd=3.14159

This number is so special that it is given its own name, "pi". We use the symbol to represent pi. Pi is an irrational number, so its decimal places go on forever without a pattern. If you have a scientific calculator, a good approximation of this number is stored in it - look for the button there.

Cd=Cd=

If we multiply both sides of this equation by dd, we get the formula for circumference of a circle:

C=dC=d

The diameter of a circle is always double the length of the radius, so d=2rd=2r. We can also write the formula as

C=2rC=2r

You can use whichever formula you prefer.

TIP:

This can help you to remember the difference between the formulas for circumference and area of a circle:

  • The formula for circumference of a circle is C=dC=d or C=2rC=2r. Circumference is measured in units of length, so nothing is squared in the circumference formula.
  • The formula for area of a circle is A=r2A=r2. Area is measured in square units, so there is a square in the area formula.
Submit your answer as:

Circles: area and units

A circle has a radius of 3 mm3 mm. What is its area in cm2cm2?

INSTRUCTION: Use =3.14=3.14 in your calculation, and round your answer to two decimal places.
Answer: The area is cm2cm2.
one-of
type(numeric.abserror(0.01))
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[0 points 3 / 3 points left]

Start by finding the radius of the circle in cmcm. Then calculate the area in cm2cm2.

STEP: Convert the radius to cmcm
[1 point 2 / 3 points left]

In this question, we need to find the area of the circle in cm2cm2, but we have the radius in mmmm. One way to solve this is to start by converting the radius to cmcm, and then use this value to find the area in cm2cm2.

We know that 1 cm=10 mm1 cm=10 mm, so we need to divide the radius in mmmm by 1010. We need to divide, because 1 mm1 mm is smaller than 1 cm1 cm, so we need fewer cmcm than we have mmmm.

r=3 mm=310 cm=0.3 cmr=3 mm=310 cm=0.3 cm
STEP: Calculate the area in cm2cm2
[2 points 0 / 3 points left]

Now we need to calculate the area of the circle in cm2cm2. The formula for the area of a circle is

A=r2A=r2

Since we know that the radius is 0.3 cm0.3 cm, we can calculate the area

A=r2=(3.14)(0.3)2=0.28260.28 cm2A=r2=(3.14)(0.3)2=0.28260.28 cm2

The correct answer for the new area of the circle is

A=0.28 cm2A=0.28 cm2

Area: concentric circles

ID is: 3418 Seed is: 4958

Area of a circle

The circle below has a radius of 2 km2 km.

What is the area of the circle?

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to two decimal places.
Answer: Area ==
one-of
type(numeric.abserror(0.01))
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[0 points 2 / 2 points left]

The formula for the area of a circle is

A=r2A=r2

Which variable is the radius in this formula?

STEP: Calculate the area of the circle
[2 points 0 / 2 points left]
The area of a shape is the surface that we can paint. Area is measured in square units, such as mm2mm2, cm2cm2, m2m2 or km2km2.

Let's start with the formula for the area of a circle:

A=r2A=r2

In this formula, the variable rr stands for the radius of the circle.

  • The radius of a circle is the distance from the centre to the circumference.
  • The diameter of a circle is the length of a line passing through the centre of the circle, and touching the circumference at both ends.
  • The diameter of a circle is always double the radius, so d=2rd=2r.

The question tells us that the radius of the circle is equal to 2km2km. We must substitute this into the formula to find the area of the circle.

A=r2=(2)2=4=12.56637...12.57 km2A=r2=(2)2=4=12.56637...12.57 km2
TIP: You should use the button on your calculator to work out the answer.

So the area of the circle is 12.57 km212.57 km2.

Submit your answer as: and

HINT: <no title>

STEP: Use the circumference to determine the radius of the circle
[2 points 2 / 4 points left]

We can substitute C=4C=4 into the formula and solve for dd by inspection:

C=d4=dd=4cmC=d4=dd=4cm

The diameter is double the radius, so r=2 cmr=2 cm.

[2 points 0 / 4 points left]

A=r2=(2)2=4cm2A=r2=(2)2=4cm2

NOTE: The equation r2=25r2=25 has two answers: 55 or 55. Here we know that rr must be a positive value, since it represents the distance from the centre to the circumference. So, we throw away the negative solution and conclude that r=5r=5.

Areas involving shapes

The following diagram shows a circle and an isosceles triangle drawn within the circle. The vertices of the triangle lie on the circumference of the circle. There is a dot at the center of the circle. The area outside the triangle is shaded.

Given that the radius of the circle is 7.917.91 m, calculate the shaded area.

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to 22 decimal places.
Answer:

The shaded area m2m2.

one-of
type(numeric.noerror)
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[0 points 5 / 5 points left]

Calculate the areas of the circle and the triangle separately and then substract the area of the triangle from the circle of the circle. Use the fact that the triangle is isosceles to find its height.

STEP: Determine the strategy
[1 point 4 / 5 points left]

We are given a circle and an isosceles triangle. The triangle is drawn within the circle. The area outside the triangle is shaded. We need to calculate the area that has been shaded. To do that, we will calculate the areas of the two shapes separately and then subtract the area of the triangle from the area of the circle.

STEP: Calculate the area of the circle
[1 point 3 / 5 points left]

The area of the circle (AcircleAcircle) is:

Acircle=r2=(7.91)2=(62.5681)=196.56348... m2Acircle=r2=(7.91)2=(62.5681)=196.56348... m2
STEP: Calculate the area of the triangle
[2 points 1 / 5 points left]

The calculation of the area of a triangle is a bit tricky. But we can use what we know about circles to find the information we need to find the triangle's area. We need to the base and the height of the triangle to calculate it's area. (Remember that the base and the height must be perpendicular.) Each vertex of the triangle is on the circumference of the circle. That means we can find the base and the height of the triangle from the radius of the circle.

We know that the radius of the circle is 7.917.91 m. The red dot is the centre of the circle, so any distance from that dot to the circle's circumference is 7.917.91 m. So we can label the diagram with the information as follows:

The height of the triangle is the same as the circle's radius. And the base of the triangle is actually one radius plus another radius. These lengths are perpendicular to each other, so we can substitute this information into the formula for the area of a triangle.

ATriangle=12bh=12(7.91+7.91)(7.91)=12(15.82)(7.91)=62.5681 m2ATriangle=12bh=12(7.91+7.91)(7.91)=12(15.82)(7.91)=62.5681 m2
STEP: Calculate the shaded area
[1 point 0 / 5 points left]

To find the shaded area, we need subtract the area of the triangle from that of the circle:

Ashaded=AcircleATriangle=(196.56348...)(62.5681)=133.99538...Round to twodecimal places134.0m2Ashaded=AcircleATriangle=(196.56348...)(62.5681)=133.99538...decimal placesRound to two134.0m2

The shaded area 134.0m2134.0m2.

Submit your answer as:

Areas involving shapes

The following diagram shows a circle and an isosceles triangle drawn within the circle. The vertices of the triangle lie on the circumference of the circle. There is a dot at the center of the circle. The area outside the triangle is shaded.

Given that the radius of the circle is 7.137.13 mm, calculate the shaded area.

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to 22 decimal places.
Answer:

The shaded area mm2mm2.

one-of
type(numeric.noerror)
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[0 points 5 / 5 points left]

Calculate the areas of the circle and the triangle separately and then substract the area of the triangle from the circle of the circle. Use the fact that the triangle is isosceles to find its height.

STEP: Determine the strategy
[1 point 4 / 5 points left]

We are given a circle and an isosceles triangle. The triangle is drawn within the circle. The area outside the triangle is shaded. We need to calculate the area that has been shaded. To do that, we will calculate the areas of the two shapes separately and then subtract the area of the triangle from the area of the circle.

STEP: Calculate the area of the circle
[1 point 3 / 5 points left]

The area of the circle (AcircleAcircle) is:

Acircle=r2=(7.13)2=(50.8369)=159.70883... mm2Acircle=r2=(7.13)2=(50.8369)=159.70883... mm2
STEP: Calculate the area of the triangle
[2 points 1 / 5 points left]

The calculation of the area of a triangle is a bit tricky. But we can use what we know about circles to find the information we need to find the triangle's area. We need to the base and the height of the triangle to calculate it's area. (Remember that the base and the height must be perpendicular.) Each vertex of the triangle is on the circumference of the circle. That means we can find the base and the height of the triangle from the radius of the circle.

We know that the radius of the circle is 7.137.13 mm. The red dot is the centre of the circle, so any distance from that dot to the circle's circumference is 7.137.13 mm. So we can label the diagram with the information as follows:

The height of the triangle is the same as the circle's radius. And the base of the triangle is actually one radius plus another radius. These lengths are perpendicular to each other, so we can substitute this information into the formula for the area of a triangle.

ATriangle=12bh=12(7.13+7.13)(7.13)=12(14.26)(7.13)=50.8369 mm2ATriangle=12bh=12(7.13+7.13)(7.13)=12(14.26)(7.13)=50.8369 mm2
STEP: Calculate the shaded area
[1 point 0 / 5 points left]

To find the shaded area, we need subtract the area of the triangle from that of the circle:

Ashaded=AcircleATriangle=(159.70883...)(50.8369)=108.87193...Round to twodecimal places108.87mm2Ashaded=AcircleATriangle=(159.70883...)(50.8369)=108.87193...decimal placesRound to two108.87mm2

The shaded area 108.87mm2108.87mm2.

Area of fishpond path

The diagram below shows a circular fishpond surrounded by a path. The diameter of the pond is 8 m8 m and the path is 3 m3 m wide all the way around.

Calculate the area of the path.

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to two decimal places.
Answer:

The area of the path is m2m2.

one-of
type(numeric.abserror(0.01))
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[0 points 5 / 5 points left]

Work out the radii of both circles.

STEP: Figure out how the path is made
[1 point 4 / 5 points left]

The path is made by taking the area of the big circle and then cutting out the area of the pond (the small circle). To calculate the area of the path, we must subtract the area of the small circle from the area of the big circle.

STEP: Determine the radii of both circles
[1 point 3 / 5 points left]
The formula for area of a circle is: A=r2A=r2.

We need to know the radii of both circles to calculate their areas.

The diameter of the fishpond is 8 m8 m. We know that d=2rd=2r, so the radius of the small circle is 4 m4 m.

The width of the path is 3 m3 m. The radius goes all the way from the centre to the circumference. So the radius of the big circle is the radius of the small circle plus the width of the path.

The radius of the big circle is 4+3=7 m4+3=7 m.

STEP: Calculate the areas of the circles
[2 points 1 / 5 points left]

Area of big circle:

A1=R2=(7)2=49mA1=R2=(7)2=49m

Area of small circle:

A2=r2=(4)2=16mA2=r2=(4)2=16m
TIP: When we have two overlapping circles, we often use RR as the variable for the radius of the big circle.
STEP: Subtract the area of the small circle from the area of the big circle, to get the area of the path
[1 point 0 / 5 points left]

Area of path:

A=A1A2=4916=33=103.67255...103.67 m2A=A1A2=4916=33=103.67255...103.67 m2

The area of the path is 103.67 m2103.67 m2.

TIP: Keep the answers in terms of until the last step.
